questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic with fever, headache, and purulent nasal discharge for the last two days. She does not have a cough, dyspnea, ear discharge, or sore throat. Her past medical history includes type 1 diabetes and allergic rhinitis. The patient was discharged from the hospital two days ago where she was admitted for treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient does not consume alcohol or use tobacco products. She uses cocaine occasionally, and her last use was four days ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Nasal examination reveals a black eschar over the nasal mucosa. Physical examination reveals periorbital edema.  She is admitted to the inpatient ward and initiated on an antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol to create micropores and increase cellular permeability. On day 9, she develops palpitations with an associated ECG as shown below. Which of the following findings would be expected on further evaluation?  


James Heilman, MD / CC BY-SA , Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient has a presentation suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis and is initiated on a medication that targets the fungal cell wall to create micropores–descriptive of amphotericin B, the treatment of choice for mucormycosis rhinosinusitis. Following treatment, she develops palpitations and ECG changes that include ST segment depression and T wave inversions (U-waves) indicative of amphotericin-induced hypokalemia.    

Amphotericin B can induce nephrotoxicity via tubular injury and vasoconstriction, which ultimately results in hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, and the RTA (normal anion gap acidosis). In fungal cells, amphotericin B binds to ergosterol, a component of the fungal cell membrane, and creates micropores. Similarly, it binds to cholesterol in host cell membranes (with lesser affinity) and increases membrane permeability. As a result, membrane electrochemical gradients are reduced, particularly between the renal tubular cells and the lumen. Potassium subsequently moves down this concentration gradient, resulting in a loss of potassium and limitated hydrogen ion secretion. Renal magnesium loss can also occur secondary to amphotericin nephrotoxicity.    

Acute kidney injury is typically the first sign of amphotericin B induced nephrotoxicity. Normally, as the sodium chloride delivery to the distal tubule increases, more NaCl diffuses into the macula densa. Tubuloglomerular feedback is initiated and afferent arteriole vasoconstriction occurs to limit NaCl losses. With amphotericin B use, permeability of macula densa cells increases and results in profound afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction, a fall in GFR, and a subsequent rise in creatinine.  

In order to limit amphotericin B associated nephrotoxicity, lipid formulations (liposomal and lipid complex) are used. Salt loading or volume expansion has also been found to be effective in limiting the fall in GFR as it reduces the sensitivity of the tubuloglomerular feedback system. Preventive measures to reduce nephrotoxicity include administering lower doses and avoiding co-administration of other nephrotoxic agents such as aminoglycosides or cyclosporine. Other adverse effects include fever, chills, and body aches. Intrathecal injections for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis can cause seizures, headache, and nerve palsies.

Option Analysis

✅ Hypokalemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wide anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A wide anion gap metabolic acidosis is frequently associated with ethylene glycol or salicylate use, diabetic ketoacidosis, and methanol poisoning. In the setting of amphotericin B, a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is more likely to occur secondary to its nephrotoxic effects. 
❌ Hypermagnesemia :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B use causes nephrotoxicity via direct renal tubular injury. This results in magnesium wasting and associated hypomagnesemia as opposed to hypermagnesemia. 
❌ Hyperkalemia :
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia is characterized by peaked T waves, prolonged PR intervals, widened QRS complexes, and sine wave patterns. The given ECG shows “U-wave” changes that are more suggestive of hypokalemia. In the setting of amphotericin administration, hypokalemia secondary to renal toxicity is much more likely. 
❌ Increase in GFR :
Incorrect: Amphotericin induces impairment in tubuloglomerular feedback. This causes profound afferent arteriole vasoconstriction, a rise in creatine, and a fall in GFR.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the clinic with a fever and a sore throat for one week. He has not had dyspnea or cough. His medical history includes diffuse large B cell lymphoma and hypertension. His current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. He began his chemotherapeutic regimen six weeks ago, including vincristine, rituximab, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, and prednisone.  He does not smoke, consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Examination of the oral cavity reveals pharyngeal exudate and erythema. The cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings are detailed below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication responsible for this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9  g/dL 
 Platelet count  90,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  4,000/mm3 
 Absolute Neutrophil count   1,200/mm3

choices.text: Free radical formation resulting in DNA damage

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of acute pharyngitis and evidence of neutropenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, suggestive of myelosuppression induced by a chemotherapeutic agent.   Most antineoplastic agents cause myelosuppression; however, the vignette also mentions pretreatment with a regimen including cyclophosphamide. Hematologic toxicity is one of cyclophosphamide's most common, dose-limiting side effects.  

Alkylating agents, like cyclophosphamide, are chemotherapeutic agents non-cell-cycle specific. They work by creating cross-links between guanine molecules on adjacent strands of DNA and subsequent inhibition of DNA strand separation.  

Another mechanism that can cause DNA damage involves adding an alkyl group to the number 7 atom of the guanine molecule. In response to this abnormal base pairing, DNA repair enzymes cause DNA strand breakage, which damages DNA resulting in cell death.  

DNA repair in somatic cells occurs in the GO phase of the cell cycle. Damaged DNA can be repaired by specific inherent mechanisms, either as a result of exogenous or endogenous factors. Repair mechanisms are unique to the particular DNA damage incurred.  



Option Analysis

❌ Defective base excision repair :
Incorrect: Base excision repair describes a mechanism of DNA repair that involves base specific glycosylases that remove altered bases and creating an apurinic/apyrimidinic site. DNA polymerase fills in the gap, and DNA ligase seals it. Base excision repair is significant in the repair of spontaneous deamination associated with nitrites; however, nitrites are not known to cause myelosuppression. 
❌ Free radical formation resulting in DNA damage :
Incorrect: Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that creates DNA damage by inducing free radical formation. These free radicals create breaks in DNA strands. Bleomycin can cause pulmonary fibrosis and skin hyperpigmentation. This patient did not receive bleomycin as part of his chemotherapeutic regimen. 
❌ Inhibition of homologous recombination:
Incorrect: Homologous DNA recombination is a mechanism of DNA repair that utilizes a complementary strand from the intact homologous dsDNA as a template to repair a strand of the damaged DNA segment. It is defective in breast and ovarian cancers with a BRCA1 mutation. It is not associated with the use of any chemotherapeutic. 
✅ Cross-linking of DNA strands :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Defective mismatch repair :
Incorrect: Patients with Lynch syndrome/HNPCC have a defective mismatch DNA repair mechanism. It is not associated with the use of any chemotherapeutic.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of headache, nausea, facial flushing, and abdominal cramps that developed shortly after drinking alcohol with friends at a party. The patient last visited his primary care physician 5 days ago and was started on a new medication. Past medical history is significant for asthma, which is managed adequately by albuterol. The patient has had 2 sexual partners over the past 3 months and uses condoms inconsistently. He occasionally consumes alcohol but does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 117/75 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. There is no focal abdominal tenderness on palpation. Side effects of a medication used to treat which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with nausea, flushing, headache, and abdominal discomfort after consuming alcohol. These findings are suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the answer choices, only ceftriaxone is associated with this side effect.

Adverse drug reactions related to cephalosporin use are usually mild and unspecific. They include diarrhea, nausea, rash, and tenderness at the injection site. Moreover, cephalosporins can cause a disulfiram-like reaction when consumed with alcohol, which can manifest in nausea and vomiting, facial flushing, and rapid heartbeat.

There is a small likelihood of cross-reactivity between penicillin and cephalosporin. As a result, a patient with penicillin allergy may also develop an allergic reaction after taking a cephalosporin.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Seasonal allergies:
Incorrect: Seasonal allergies are usually treated with antihistamines, which can be dangerous when used with alcohol. This combination intensifies the depressant and sedative effects of antihistamines. However, antihistamines do not cause a disulfiram-like reaction when consumed with alcohol.  
❌ Anxiety:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines are the agents of choice for anxiety. They can be dangerous when used with alcohol, as this combination intensifies the depressant and sedative effects of benzodiazepines. However, benzodiazepines do not cause a disulfiram-like reaction when consumed with alcohol.  
❌ Gastritis:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors and antacids are usually used in the management of gastritis. Neither of these are associated with the development of disulfiram-like reactions when consumed with alcohol.  
❌ Major depressive disorder:
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the first-line agent in the management of major depressive disorder. SSRIs do not cause a disulfiram-like reaction when consumed with alcohol.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the office with a complaint of blurry vision for the past few days. The patient also reports intermittent headaches and poor sleep. Review of systems reveals constipation and the sensation of bladder fullness. The patient lives alone and her son visits her occasionally. The patient does not report any recent trauma or infections. Past medical history is significant for chronic migraine headaches, hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include simvastatin, lisinopril, sumatriptan and over-the-counter diphenhydramine for insomnia. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a well-appearing woman with flushed cheeks and dilated pupils. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s blurred vision is most likely a side effect related to diphenhydramine use.  Diphenhydramine is an H1 receptor antagonist. First and second generation H1 receptor antagonists are primarily indicated in the treatment of allergic reactions, such as urticaria, angioedema, and allergic rhinitis.  However, first-generation H1 blockers are associated with multiple side effects, which are important to keep in mind as they can be taken advantage of in the treatment of other conditions or result in unwanted adverse effects. As demonstrated in this patient, the sedative properties of first-generation H1 antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine or hydroxyzine) are helpful in treating insomnia, but other adverse effects such as blurred vision can also occur.

Common side effects of first-generation H1 blockers can be subdivided into antihistaminic effects, such as sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain; antimuscarinic effects, or atropine-like side effects, such as dilated pupils, blurry vision, and dry mouth; and anti-α-adrenergic effects, like orthostatic hypotension and dizziness.

Second-generation H1 blockers (e.g., cetirizine, loratadine or fexofenadine) have far less lipid solubility, and are therefore less likely to cause cognitive side effects. Moreover, antimuscarinic side effects also tend to be less severe in second-generation H1 blockers.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Add propranolol for migraine prophylaxis:
Incorrect: Although migraine prophylaxis with propranolol could be considered in this patient, discontinuing unnecessary medications takes priority.  
❌ Decrease the dose of lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril does affect vision or level of consciousness. Moreover, the patient’s blood pressure is within normal limits.  
✅ Discontinue diphenhydramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recommend cystography:
Incorrect: This patient’s urinary retention is most likely due to the anticholinergic side effects of diphenhydramine and cystography is not recommended as the next best step in management.  
❌ Head CT scan:
Incorrect: Obtaining a head CT scan in a patient with chronic headaches is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful erection that has been present for several hours. The patient is writhing in pain. He has not been taking any male enhancement medications. An ultrasound is performed, and direct evacuation of the corpus cavernosa is performed with a needle. Upon review of the patient’s medical history, a medication is identified to be the likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Which of the following medications was this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with priapism, which is a painful long-term erection. Trazodone is an antidepressant that can cause priapism as a side effect.    

Trazodone is a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor that has potent antidepressant and sedative effects. Trazodone has several adverse effects including liver toxicity, arrhythmia, orthostatic hypotension, sedation, and priapism. Priapism affects approximately 1 in 6000 patients taking trazodone, making it a relatively rare adverse effect. The mechanism wherein trazodone causes priapism is not well understood. However, some studies suggest that this side effect is due to trazodone’s α-adrenergic antagonist properties.   

Option Analysis

✅ Trazodone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rituximab:
 Incorrect: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of certain leukemias. It does not cause priapism as a side effect.  
❌ Bupropion:
Incorrect: Bupropion is a norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor used to treat depression. It does not cause priapism as a side effect.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a ꞵ-blocker used to treat conditions including arrhythmias, tremors, and performance anxiety. It does not cause priapism as a side effect.   
❌ Phenylephrine :
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic agent that is primarily used as a decongestant. It does not cause priapism as a side effect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer and started on high-dose oxycodone to manage severe bone pain. Two weeks later, the patient returns to the office because of increasingly hard, small volume, and difficult to pass stools with associated bloating. She has tried a high fiber diet, polyethylene glycol, and bisacodyl without significant symptomatic improvement. However, she has experienced significant improvement in bone pain. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen and decreased bowel sounds. Which of the following µ-receptor antagonists can be used to help in the management of this patient’s symptoms without precipitating symptoms of opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has opioid-induced constipation (OIC), which occurs due to the effects that opioid medications have on μ-receptors in the enteric nervous system. The net result is decreased intestinal peristalsis. Patients should manage with laxative therapy (e.g. polyethylene glycol). Those with refractory OIC can be treated with methylnaltrexone, a peripherally acting µ-receptor antagonist.

Two new opioid receptor antagonists, methylnaltrexone and alvimopan, do not cross the blood-brain barrier. They can block the adverse effects of strong opioids on peripheral µ-receptors while having minimal effects on its analgesic actions and not precipitating symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Methylnaltrexone effectively treats constipation in patients with OIC, whereas alvimopan is used to treat postoperative ileus following bowel surgery.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a µ-receptor antagonist that can cross the blood-brain barrier and induce opioid withdrawal symptoms. It is indicated in the treatment of acute opioid toxicity.  
✅ Methylnaltrexone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loperamide:
Incorrect: Loperamide is an opioid-based medication that inhibits peristalsis in the gastrointestinal tract. It is used to treat diarrhea and can worsen this patient’s constipation.  
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is an osmotically active agent that draws water into the intestinal lumen. It is effective in managing constipation but does not act on the µ-receptor.  
❌ Docusate:
Incorrect: Docusate is a surfactant that decreases stool surface tension, enabling water to enter and soften the stools. It effectively manages opioid-induced constipation but does not act on the µ-receptor.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department following a first-time seizure. The patient was recently seen in the emergency department for symptomatic nephrolithiasis and was discharged with pain medications and urology follow-up. Her roommate, who is at the bedside, does not recall which medication she was prescribed. Past medical history includes depression, chronic pain, anxiety, and hypertension. Her current medications include sertraline, venlafaxine, amlodipine, and alprazolam. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 163/105 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a confused postictal individual with diaphoresis and mydriasis. Clonus and hyperreflexia are elicited in the lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of serotonin syndrome, including new-onset seizure, mydriasis, diaphoresis, autonomic dysfunction, clonus, and hyperreflexia. This patient, who is already on several serotonergic agents, was likely provided with an additional medication with this pharmacological activity. Of the medications listed, only tramadol is associated with an increased risk of serotonin syndrome.    

Tramadol and meperidine are two opiate medications that, apart from opiate receptor agonism, carry additional mechanisms of action. Tramadol functions as a weak opioid agonist and inhibits norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake. These effects on both norepinephrine and serotonin are thought to activate descending pain modulation pathways. Meperidine functions as a full opiate agonist and inhibits dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine reuptake.    

Based on these additional mechanisms of action, tramadol and meperidine predispose at-risk patients to develop serotonin syndrome and can lower the seizure threshold (via excitation of the central nervous system). These medications should be prescribed with caution to individuals taking other serotonergic agents, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs).   

Option Analysis

✅ Tramadol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fentanyl:
Incorrect: Fentanyl is an opiate agonist with a rapid onset of action. Fentanyl patches are often used for the treatment of chronic pain. However, it is less likely than tramadol to precipitate serotonin syndrome.   
❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is a pure opiate receptor agonist. This medication does not carry serotonergic properties and is unlikely to cause serotonin syndrome, even with another serotonergic medication.   
❌ Oxycodone :
Incorrect: Oxycodone is an oral opiate receptor agonist used for the treatment of acute severe pain. This medication does not carry serotonergic properties and would be unlikely to precipitate serotonin syndrome.  
❌ Ketorolac:
Incorrect: Ketorolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medication. This medication does not carry serotonergic properties and would be unlikely to precipitate serotonin syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found confused at home with scattered pill bottles at the bedside. Past medical history is notable for depression, anxiety, and peripheral neuropathy. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), respirations are 22/min, pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg.  Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, mydriasis, and urinary retention. An electrocardiogram demonstrates QT prolongation. A medication overdose is suspected, and the patient is empirically administered ammonium chloride to enhance renal drug excretion. Which of the following medications did this patient most likely ingest?
questions.solution:
This patient presents clinical features concerning tricyclic antidepressant overdose, including antimuscarinic toxidrome findings and QT prolongation on an electrocardiogram. Given that these medications are weak bases, patients presenting with overdose are often treated with ammonium chloride, which enhances renal excretion of these substances.    

Several medications are considered weak bases, including tricyclic antidepressants and amphetamines, among many others. Historically, an adjunct to overdose treatment with these medications involves administering ammonium chloride, which has been shown to reduce total body pH. The drug molecules are weak bases and will exist primarily in protonated charged form. The charged molecules are less likely to induce toxicity by crossing the blood-brain barrier and have enhanced elimination in the urine. The latter phenomenon is because charged particles have a more challenging time back-diffusing across the renal epithelium into the systemic circulation.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  



Option Analysis

✅ Amitriptyline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate (not ammonium chloride) can be administered to alkalize the urine, cause aspirin to deprotonate, and trap the polarized drug molecules in the renal tubules. These changes can increase aspirin elimination via urine.  
❌ Phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increaelimination via urine.  
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in case of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.

Her past medical history is significant for dysmenorrhea and migraine headaches. She takes no regular medications and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. choices.text: Monitor liver function tests every 4 hours

questions.solution:
The patient who has been ingesting acetaminophen and presents with malaise, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, along with substantially elevated AST and ALT levels, likely has acetaminophen hepatotoxicity despite the initial undetectable acetaminophen level. Immediate administration of N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is essential for managing this toxicity.

For patients presenting after 24 hours or an unknown duration post-ingestion, management is guided by acetaminophen (APAP) levels and liver function enzymes. If APAP levels are undetectable and liver enzymes (AST and ALT) are within the normal range, an alternative diagnosis should be considered. However, even if APAP is not present in the bloodstream, elevated AST and ALT levels can indicate acetaminophen toxicity in the right clinical context. In such instances, the immediate course of action is to initiate management with NAC which acts as an antidote, replenishing glutathione stores, thus preventing further liver damage.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharging the patient without addressing the potential acetaminophen toxicity is not appropriate. The elevated liver enzymes suggest ongoing liver injury, which requires immediate intervention rather than outpatient monitoring.  
❌ Monitor liver function tests every 4 hours:
Incorrect: While it is essential to keep track of liver function levels in suspected acetaminophen toxicity, monitoring won't prevent the progression of liver damage. Immediate intervention with NAC is necessary.  
❌ Perform gastric lavage:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage aims to prevent further absorption of ingested toxins and is most effective if performed within 4 hours of ingestion. Given the patient's uncertainty about the timing of ingestion and the presence of liver injury, NAC should be administered to prevent further liver damage.  
❌ Consult liver transplant team:
Incorrect: Liver transplantation is considered for patients with acetaminophen toxicity who display signs of liver failure and have unfavorable prognostic indicators. This patient does not have advanced features, such as markedly elevated PT/INR and metabolic acidosis. The immediate treatment priority is to start NAC therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son after being unresponsive on his bedroom floor with an empty pill bottle beside him. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and major depressive disorder. His temperature is 37.7°C (100F), pulse is 35/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals cold and clammy extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates bilateral wheezing. An ECG strip is shown below. Atropine and intravenous fluids are administered. After administering 3 mg atropine, Reevaluation shows no improvement in blood pressure and ECG. In addition to oxygenation, which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypotension, first-degree heart block, and bilateral wheezing consistent with beta-blocker toxicity. Overdose of calcium channel blockers, digoxin, and cholinergic agents can present similar symptoms, but wheezing is atypical.    

Beta-adrenergic–blocking agents are widely used to treat hypertension, arrhythmias, angina pectoris, heart failure, migraine, and glaucoma. Presentation of beta-blocker toxicity can be divided into:  
  •  Cardiac disturbances: first-degree heart block, hypotension, and bradycardia 
  •  Central nervous system toxicity: convulsions, coma, and respiratory arrest 
  •  Bronchospasm 
  •  Hypoglycemia and hyperkalemia 

Management includes administration of isotonic fluid boluses and atropine to treat hypotension and bradycardia. Resistant or profound hypotension and bradycardia require the administration of glucagon.  This medication increases intracellular cAMP and has effectively treated both beta and calcium channel blocker toxicity. Other therapies include epinephrine, high-dose insulin with glucose, and IV lipid emulsion therapy.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ Digoxin-specific antibody:
Incorrect: Digoxin-specific antibody serves as the antidote for digoxin toxicity which presents with fatigue, anorexia, nausea, blurred vision, disturbed color perception, and cardiac arrhythmias. Wheezing is atypical.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone serves as the antidote for opioid overdose, which presents with depressed mental status, decreased respiratory rate, and bradycardia. 
❌ Methylene blue:
Incorrect: Methylene blue is the antidote for methemoglobinemia, usually caused by nitrites, dapsone, or benzocaine. The severity of symptoms depends on the percentage of hemoglobin oxidized to methemoglobin. It can present with dizziness, nausea, headache, dyspnea, and confusion. Hypotension and first-degree AV block are atypical. 
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Membrane-depressant effects (wide QRS interval) may respond to boluses of sodium bicarbonate for tricyclic antidepressant poisoning. This patient’s ECG is suggestive of first-degree AV block.
✅ Glucagon:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician with a fever and sore throat. The patient’s symptoms started two days ago. She was diagnosed with a partial seizure last month and was started on anti-epileptic medication. Temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and pulse is 89 beats per minute. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?

 Erythrocyte count   5 million (cells/mcL) 
 Hemoglobin   13 (g/dL) 
 Mean corpuscular volume   80 (fL) 
 Leukocyte count   1500 (cells/mm3) 
 Absolute Neutrophil count   80 (cells/mm3) 
 Platelets count   200,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever, sore throat, and low absolute neutrophil count, indicative of agranulocytosis. This patient’s agranulocytosis likely resulted from the use of carbamazepine.  Other common side effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, ataxia, and stevens-johnson syndrome. Side effects of associated anti-epileptic medications are listed in the chart detailed below.



Option Analysis

✅ Carbamazepine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lamotrigine :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine’s side-effect profile include Stevens-Johnson syndrome and hemophagocytic  lymphohistiocytosis. Lamotrigine is not associated with agranulocytosis.   
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Common side effects of levetiracetam include neuropsychiatric manifestations, headache, and drowsiness. Agranulocytosis is not associated with the use of this medication. 
❌ Gabapentin :
Incorrect: Gabapentin use can lead to sedation and ataxia, but it is not associated with agranulocytosis. 
❌ Vigabatrin :
Incorrect: Vigabatrin’s side effects include permanent vision loss but not agranulocytosis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner after a medication overdose. The partner became concerned when the patient appeared confused and had slurred speech. She has had two episodes of non-bloody emesis. Several empty medication bottles were found in the bathroom. The patient recently lost her job as a phlebotomist and has been under significant stress. Medical history is notable for depression, asthma, and latent tuberculosis. She is taking an antidepressant, an albuterol inhaler, and an antimycobacterial drug. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 112/70 mmHg, and pulse is 130/min. An EKG is obtained and shown below. The patient is oriented only to self. Bilateral pupils are reactive to light. 2+ reflexes are present in the extremities. The patient develops a tonic-clonic seizure lasting 5 minutes that is refractory to lorazepam therapy during the physical examination. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, and vomiting. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia but no QRS interval prolongation. She later develops a tonic-clonic seizure that is refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. Based on these findings, the patient most likely overdosed on isoniazid.  

Isoniazid can be used as monotherapy for the treatment of latent tuberculosis. The medication inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, an essential component of the mycobacterial cell wall. It also inhibits mycobacterial peroxidase, which leads to hydrogen peroxide accumulation within mycobacteria and subsequent cellular damage.    
Patients with isoniazid toxicity will initially present with relatively nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, and confusion. Later on, patients can develop seizures, metabolic acidosis, and coma.    

Seizures develop since isoniazid causes vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Pyridoxine is normally converted to pyridoxal phosphate and used to synthesize the inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In the setting of pyridoxine deficiency, GABA levels are reduced, and the risk of seizures is elevated. Often, the seizures that occur are intractable and refractory to benzodiazepine therapy.     

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Many patients with fluoxetine overdose remain asymptomatic, whereas others may develop nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, agitation, or tachycardia. In rare cases, patients can develop serotonin syndrome, presenting with altered mental status, autonomic instability, and hyperreflexia. Although seizures have been reported in the setting of fluoxetine overdose, the incidence rate is extremely low.  
❌ Ethambutol:
Incorrect: This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, and vomiting. She develops a tonic-clonic seizure that is refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. These symptoms are consistent with isoniazid overdose. In contrast, ethambutol toxicity is more likely to present with visual disturbances (e.g., blurry vision, color blindness).   
✅ Isoniazid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant. This patient has a normal QRS interval and lacks anticholinergic symptoms. Overdose can lead to anticholinergic symptoms (e.g., mydriasis, flushed skin), altered mental status, seizures, and QRS interval prolongation.   
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with confusion, slurred speech, vomiting, and a tonic-clonic seizure refractory to benzodiazepine therapy. These symptoms are consistent with isoniazid overdose. Although rifampin toxicity can also cause seizures, it will likely be preceded by orange discoloration of the skin and body fluids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for an evaluation of stomach aches. She has been experiencing decreased appetite, vomiting, and occasional palpitations for the last two weeks. The patient also reports reduced color perception. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure controlled with multiple medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. ECG shows atrial tachycardia with AV block. Laboratory results are displayed below. Increased level of which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with congestive heart failure has signs and symptoms of digoxin toxicity.

Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index, making toxicity relatively a common occurrence. Digoxin toxicity symptoms are non-specific and include nausea, vomiting, fatigue, confusion, dizziness, blurred vision, and altered color perception (specifically, yellow and green, known as xanthopsia). A wide range of arrhythmias occurring at almost any intracardiac location can be seen with digoxin toxicity. It can include sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation. The arrhythmias are thought to result from increased calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which increases the cardiac contractility (secondary to the direct inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase, which indirectly inhibits the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger).

Hypokalemia can precipitate toxicity by increasing digoxin binding at K+-binding sites on Na+/K+ ATPase. In contrast, hyperkalemia is a sign of digoxin toxicity as the inhibition of Na+/K+ ATPase increases extracellular potassium. Other factors that increase the risk of digoxin toxicity include:

  • Hypomagnesemia (which leads to hypokalemia)
  • Renal failure (decreased digoxin clearance)
  • Hypovolemia 
 


Option Analysis

❌ Atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Atorvastatin, a statin medication, is used to prevent cardiovascular disease in those at high risk and treat abnormal lipid levels. The most common side effects include myopathy and, more rarely, rhabdomyolysis.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Beta-blocker overdose can cause bradycardia and profound hypotension instead of tachycardia seen in this patient. Moreover, it typically causes bronchospasm and hypoglycemia, whereas anorexia and vomiting are more likely with digoxin toxicity.  
✅ Digoxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is more likely to cause hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia due to volume depletion.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril overdose is associated with the development of hypokalemia, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. This patient's serum creatinine and blood pressure are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a dry, nagging cough. He does not have chest pain or shortness of breath. The rest of the review of systems is within normal limits. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/85 mmHg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine of 1.2 mg/dL and potassium of 4.9 mEq/L. Chest x-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s dry nagging cough is most likely a side effect of lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor.  

The cough usually begins within one to two weeks of instituting therapy, but it can be delayed by up to six months. It is thought to result from increased local concentrations of kinins, the substance P, and prostaglandins. Inhibition of bradykinin and substance P breakdown by ACEI results in their increased concentration, which may induce bronchial irritation and cough via enhanced production of prostaglandins. Moreover, ACE inhibition may also activate the arachidonic pathway, which leads to elevated levels of thromboxane, potentiating bronchoconstriction.    

Treatment includes replacing ACE inhibitors with angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), which does not affect bradykinin levels and does not cause cough.  

Option Analysis

❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that can increase the excretion of potassium in the urine, leading to hypokalemia (in contrast to hyperkalemia in this patient). Moreover, it does not cause a dry cough.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Metformin increases insulin sensitivity in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and does not cause cough or hyperkalemia.  
❌ Amiodarone:
Incorrect: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can cause pulmonary fibrosis, which may present with cough. This patient’s chest x-ray is normal.  
❌ Digoxin:
Incorrect: Although digoxin may cause hyperkalemia, it is unlikely to cause dry cough as a side effect.  
✅ Lisinopril:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the office for the evaluation of episodic facial redness, warmth and pruritus. She reports pruritus and facial flushing for the past 5 days that lasts for approximately 2 hours before bedtime and resolves on its own. The remainder of the system review is unremarkable. She was recently started on a lipid lowering drug for her dyslipidemia. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in her father. She has been working as a gardener near her neighborhood for the past 10 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows a healthy young female with normal skin on inspection. The lungs are clear to auscultation and there are no heart murmurs. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer aspirin 30 minutes before taking her medication
Counsel the patient to avoid sunlight

questions.solution:
This patient’s episodic facial flushing is most likely due to the ingestion of niacin, a lipid lowering drug, which tends to cause prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation at high doses. The role of prostaglandins (released by cutaneous macrophage) is confirmed by the improvement in flushing and pruritus when non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), particularly aspirin, are taken 30 minutes before niacin at bedtime. The flushing and pruritus usually improves after 2-4 weeks of niacin therapy. It is better tolerated when ingested with food. A new drug, laropiprant, a prostaglandin D2 antagonist, is also proven to treat niacin flush.

Other side effects of niacin include reversible increase in liver aminotransferases, postural hypotension, gastrointestinal upset, elevations in serum uric acid levels and increase in glucose levels. When used in combination with statins, it increases the risk of developing myopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer antihistamine:
Incorrect: This patient’s facial flushing is most likely secondary to prostaglandin-induced vasodilation, not mast cell degranulation. Hence, it is unlikely to improve with the use of antihistamines.  
❌ Reassure the patient  :
Incorrect: Although patient’s on niacin therapy will become tolerant to this effect with long-term use, active use of aspirin before administering niacin is the most appropriate step at this point.  
❌ Measure 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA)  :
Incorrect: 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is measured in suspected cases of carcinoid syndrome. In addition to flushing, symptoms of diarrhea and bronchospasm and/or a history of valvular heart disease are usually present.  
✅ Administer aspirin 30 minutes before taking her medication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Counsel the patient to avoid sunlight:
Incorrect: Exposure to sunlight is the major trigger for the exacerbation of acne rosacea, which usually presents with erythematous rash of the central face (nose and cheeks). This patient had an acute episode of facial flushing, most likely triggered by a medication.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic for new-onset palpitations for the past 3 months. The symptoms occur “out of the blue” for a few seconds at a time. Past medical history is unremarkable. He recalls that his mother had been taking a medication for many years for a chronic condition, but he cannot remember the medication’s name. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/83 mmHg, and pulse is 71/min. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide splitting of the second heart sound. An electrocardiogram is significant for tall broad P waves, prolonged PR intervals, and right bundle branch block. A cardiac echocardiogram shows downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets. Exposure to which of the following agents in utero most likely contributed to this patient’s cardiac defect?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with arrhythmias, downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and right bundle branch block. These findings are concerning for Ebstein anomaly, which is caused by in utero exposure to lithium.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by downward displacement of the tricuspid valve leaflets and atrialization of the right ventricle. Ebstein anomalies may present at any point in life.

Severe disease presents with cardiomegaly, hydrops, and tachyarrhythmias. Affected patients often die in utero. The moderate disease can present with cyanosis, congestive heart failure secondary to tricuspid valve regurgitation, and marked cardiomegaly. Patients with moderate disease may present with progressive right-sided heart failure in childhood. Finally, the mild disease often presents with arrhythmias, fatigue, progressive cyanosis, and right-sided heart failure during childhood or adulthood.

Most patients will have an abnormal electrocardiogram with tall and broad P-waves (secondary to right atrial enlargement) and a complete or incomplete right bundle branch block. Symptomatic patients may be managed surgically if they are appropriate candidates. If not, they can be medically managed and treated with a standard heart failure regimen of diuretics and digoxin.  

Option Analysis

❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: Exposure to methimazole has been associated with aplasia cutis. Patients with this condition have a congenital absence of skin, often presenting as a round area without skin on the scalp. Methimazole treats hyperthyroidism through inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. However, the medication has not been associated with the Ebstein anomaly.  
✅ Lithium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethanol:
Incorrect: Patients with exposure to alcohol in utero may suffer from fetal alcohol syndrome. This condition classically presents with facial features including a smooth philtrum, thin vermillion, and small palpebral fissures. Another primary feature is central nervous system damage. In contrast, in utero alcohol exposure has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Thalidomide:
Incorrect: Thalidomide was originally developed as a treatment for morning sickness in pregnant women. It is classically associated with phocomelia, which is the absence and/or underdevelopment of the limbs. However, thalidomide has not been associated with Ebstein anomaly.  
❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Spironolactone is an anti-androgen agent that is used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and hormonal acne. There is a theoretical risk of feminization of a male fetus if exposed in utero, though this concern is not well documented in the literature.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient took multiple tablets of acetaminophen three hours ago for right foot pain that began several days ago after beginning an intense exercise regimen. The patient has not had any suicidal thoughts, hallucinations, or a history of psychiatric illness. The patient had a runny nose, sinus congestion, and headaches last week. Medications include an oral contraceptive. The patient had one glass of wine last night and normally drinks 2-3 alcoholic drinks per week. The patient does not use tobacco or recreational drugs. Menarche was at age 13, and her last menstrual period was 3 months ago. The patient’s temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 52/min, and blood pressure is 98/68 mmHg. BMI is 15.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals soft, unpigmented hair on the face, arms, and legs. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following factors likely predisposed this patient to her current illness?
questions.solution:
This young adult female is presenting with signs of early acetaminophen toxicity (e.g., abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting). The patient likely has anorexia nervosa given an irregular menstrual cycle, bradycardia, hypotension, reduced BMI, and physical examination findings demonstrating lanugo (e.g., soft, unpigmented hair).

Malnutrition predisposes patients to acetaminophen hepatotoxicity. Hepatocytes mainly metabolize acetaminophen by glucuronidation and sulfation to non-toxic metabolites, which are excreted in urine. A small amount of acetaminophen is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine, or NAPQI. The hepatic process of glucuronidation relies on hepatic carbohydrate reserves, and in the fasting or malnourished state, glucuronidation of acetaminophen is reduced, which leads to increased microsomal metabolism and subsequent production of NAPQI. Normally, this toxic metabolite is inactivated by an antioxidant called glutathione. In therapeutic doses, acetaminophen does not cause severe side effects. However, depleted glutathione stores, also associated with the fasting and malnourished state, compromise detoxification of NAPQI and predispose to hepatic injury.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 



Option Analysis

❌ Age of patient:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen metabolism is age-dependent, with decreased metabolism and increased risk of toxicity occurring with increasing age. This patient is a young adult, making her age an unlikely cause of acetaminophen toxicity.   
✅ Malnutrition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Recent consumption of alcohol   :
Incorrect: Acute alcohol ingestion is not a significant risk factor for hepatotoxicity; in contrast, it may be protective by competing with acetaminophen for CYP2E1 and, thereby, decreasing the amount of NAPQI produced. Chronic alcohol consumption, in contrast, depletes glutathione stores and synthesis, as well as induces CYP enzymes, resulting in the accumulation of the toxic metabolite NAPQI.   
❌ Recent viral illness   :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is the first-line therapy for children with fever or pain since aspirin can cause Reye’s syndrome, which is a life-threatening condition that can occur after a viral infection.   
❌ Use of oral contraceptives   :
Incorrect: Medications that induce CYP2E1 enzymes can result in acetaminophen toxicity; since a small amount of acetaminophen is also metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes (also known as microsomal metabolism) to a highly toxic metabolite, N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine or NAPQI. CYP inducers can result in elevated NAPQI byproducts. These medications include anticonvulsants, antituberculosis agents, as well as some herbal medications. Oral contraceptive pills are substrates of cytochrome P-450 but are not known to induce these enzymes.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The patient had undergone a lung transplant 8 months ago and has had several episodes of cytomegalovirus infections since then. Two days ago, the patient was diagnosed with CMV retinitis and was started on an antiviral agent that does not require intracellular activation and is known to bind in-vitro with virally encoded enzymes, such as DNA polymerase and RNA polymerase. Laboratory results are shown below. ECG shows nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves. Which of the following agents is the most likely cause of this patient’s current presentation?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Calcium  6.5 mg/dL 
 Magnesium  0.9 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s generalized tonic-clonic seizure is likely secondary to severe hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. He is also found to have hypokalemia with ECG changes (nonspecific ST changes and inverted T waves). These electrolyte abnormalities likely resulted from the initiation of forcarnet.  

Foscarnet is an inorganic pyrophosphate analog that inhibits herpesvirus DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase directly without requiring activation by phosphorylation. Foscarnet blocks the pyrophosphate binding site of these enzymes and inhibits cleavage of pyrophosphate from deoxynucleotide triphosphates, leading to chain termination. It is indicated for the treatment of acyclovir-resistant HSV infections. It is also used as an alternative to ganciclovir for the prophylaxis and treatment of CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals.    

Major adverse effects include nephrotoxicity and electrolyte abnormalities (hypo- or hypercalcemia, hypo- or hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia) that can lead to seizures. The principal mode of viral resistance to the drug involves mutation of the DNA polymerase.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cidofovir:
Incorrect: Although cidofovir is effective against CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients, it is usually associated with nephrotoxicity, causing elevated creatinine levels. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.
✅ Foscarnet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is associated with the development of crystal nephropathy and requires activation by viral kinase.
❌ Didanosine:
Incorrect: Didanosine is an antiretroviral medication that is associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen and it is not effective against CMV retinitis.
❌ Valganciclovir:
Incorrect: Valganciclovir is a prodrug of ganciclovir. It is typically associated with the development of bone marrow suppression. Electrolyte disturbances are not usually seen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of painful skin lesions. The patient has erythematous erosions over the face, limbs, trunk, and oral cavity. Before developing this rash, he developed fever, chills, and sore throat three days ago. He was diagnosed with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure disorder six months ago and is currently taking lamotrigine. The patient is ill-appearing. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 117/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 94%. Skin examination reveals blistering lesions and erosions in the oral cavity, face, upper limb, and trunk. A lateral pressure to the skin results in the shedding of the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). SJS is a life-threatening type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by cytotoxic T-cells (CD8+ T-cells). The condition is characterized by necrosis of the epithelium of the skin and mucosal membranes, resulting in blistering lesions and erosions, fever, and systemic illness. Involved areas typically include the skin of the face, trunk, and limbs and mucous membranes.  

Many common medications can trigger SJS. Anticonvulsants associated with SJS include lamotrigine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and ethosuximide. 


Option Analysis

✅ Stevens-Johnson syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Erythema multiforme :
Incorrect: This patient’s skin lesions, involvement of mucosal membranes, fever, and history of lamotrigine use suggest Stevens-Johnson syndrome. 
❌ Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome :
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded-skin syndrome is associated with blistering lesions, skin tenderness, and fever; however, mucosal membranes are spared. This condition is more commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
❌ Pemphigus Vulgaris :
Incorrect: Pemphigus Vulgaris can present with blisters, mucosal lesions, and fever, but it is primarily seen in older patients. Also, the association with using lamotrigine makes Stevens-Johnson syndrome the more likely diagnosis. 
❌ Bullous pemphigoid:
Incorrect: Bullous pemphigoid is a blistering disorder characterized by tense bullae that are usually itchy and may turn painful with time. Mucosal lesions can sometimes be seen, but fever is rare.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to concerns regarding a persistent facial rash. The patient started noticing that the skin on the tip of his nose, cheeks, and chin had been turning "blue." The rash seems to worsen while he is out in the sun. He has otherwise been feeling well. Several weeks ago, he was given procainamide in the emergency department for atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Medical history is also notable for congestive heart failure, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. He has a 10-pack-year smoking history and consumes one to two beers daily. Current medications include losartan, amiodarone, carvedilol, and warfarin. Physical examination reveals the findings below. Which of the following is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s clinical presentation? 


Image reproduced from DermNetNZ
questions.solution:
Blue-gray skin discoloration (ceruloderma) is a rare but classic side effect of amiodarone therapy, which is more common in males than females.  

Amiodarone is a lipophilic drug used in the treatment of arrhythmias. The mechanism of skin discoloration is mainly undefined but is thought to be due to brownish-yellow deposits of amiodarone, iron, and other substances (not including melanin or hemosiderin) in tissue histiocytes near dermal blood vessels. The discoloration appears in sun-exposed areas and is thought to be triggered by a UV-related hypersensitivity response. 

Class III antiarrhythmic medications generally carry several side effects, but most importantly, torsade de pointe due to QT interval prolongation. Unlike other class III antiarrhythmics, Amiodarone has several unique side effects apart from ceruloderma. Amiodarone acts as a hapten, which can induce pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, and corneal microdeposits. For this reason, pulmonary and liver function testing may be obtained for patients starting amiodarone. In addition, amiodarone is 40% iodine by weight and has a propensity to be taken up by the thyroid gland and induce thyroid dysfunction. For this reason, baseline thyroid function tests should be obtained.     

Option Analysis

✅ Amiodarone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class I antiarrhythmic agent that can precipitate a lupus-like reaction. However, this side effect is dose-dependent and unlikely to be caused by a single dose of procainamide administered several weeks ago. Furthermore, this patient’s findings are more consistent with ceruloderma (blue-gray hyperpigmentation) rather than an erythematous lupus butterfly rash. 
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is associated with acanthosis nigricans, which tend to appear brown-to-black, poorly defined, velvety areas of hyperpigmentation found within body folds. 
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin can cause severe skin necrosis if it is not appropriately bridged with heparin. It is not known to cause ceruloderma (blue-gray hyperpigmentation). 
❌ Niacin deficiency:
Incorrect: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency is associated with severe alcoholism and nutritional deficiency. Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which manifests with peeling, redness, scaling, and thickening of sun-exposed areas of skin.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office because of a five-day history of high fevers. The fevers occur intermittently, and he has not noticed a pattern as to when they occur. The fevers are accompanied by muscle aches, chills, and night sweats. He lives in Massachusetts and recently returned from a global surgery trip to Africa. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Peripheral blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. After further evaluation, the patient is started on high-dose quinine. This medication is associated with which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregular pattern of fevers, chills, and myalgias after returning from a malaria-endemic area. In addition, a blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. These findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection. The patient is started on high-dose quinine therapy and is at increased risk of developing cinchonism, which constellates gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus symptoms.

Apart from quinine, other quinoline-based antimalarial medications include quinidine and chloroquine. These medications can all cause gastrointestinal distress and headaches. Quinidine can also cause cinchonism as well as arrhythmias and long QT syndrome. As a result, the medication should be avoided in individuals with cardiac problems. Chloroquine can cause pruritus and, if used over long periods, can cause retinopathy, which is reversible if the medication is stopped.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nocturnal leg cramps:
Incorrect: Quinine is moderately effective in decreasing the frequency and intensity of muscle cramps. As a result, nocturnal leg cramps are not a side effect of quinine therapy.  
❌ Diabetic retinopathy:
Incorrect: Quinine is not known to cause diabetic retinopathy.  
✅ Cinchonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Tetracycline, vitamin A derivatives, and oral contraceptives, but not quinine, are associated with an increased risk of developing idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  
❌ Psychosis and seizure:
Incorrect: Oral mefloquine is generally well tolerated. However, the United States FDA has added a “black box” warning to mefloquine, noting the drug’s potential to cause severe, possibly permanent, neurological and psychiatric adverse effects. However, quinine therapy has not been associated with these side effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past seven days. The patient returned from his cousin’s wedding in Africa three weeks ago. The patient was prescribed chemoprophylaxis but did not take it regularly. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and an enlarged spleen. Peripheral blood smear shows trophozoites and schizonts. Appropriate treatment is started, and the patient is discharged. He returns to the emergency department 2-days later following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His partner, accompanying him, recalls that the patient showed signs of improvement until the seizure. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s complication?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on an antimalarial regimen that likely included mefloquine, often used with artesunate to treat chloroquine-resistant malaria.

Common adverse effects of mefloquine include gastrointestinal distress, skin rash, headache, and dizziness. Mefloquine can cause cardiac conduction defects and neuropsychiatric complications (e.g., seizures, psychosis, depression).  

Option Analysis

❌ Primaquine:
Incorrect: Primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and is contraindicated in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine can cause pruritus and its long term use can cause retinopathy. It is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine has been associated with cinchonism, a constellation of gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus. In addition, the medication is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmias and long QT syndrome.  
✅ Mefloquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline associated with esophageal ulceration, photosensitivity, and gastrointestinal discomfort. It is not associated with an increased risk of seizures.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to altered mental status. According to the roommate, the patient appeared confused and mumbled about how “spies” were trying to sabotage her homework assignment. Past medical history is notable for depression for which she takes fluoxetine. Earlier in the day, the patient visited her university health clinic due to cold symptoms and was prescribed an antitussive. Temperature is 40.2°C (104.4°F), blood pressure is 157/96 mmHg, and pulse is 126/min. The patient is oriented to self but not place or time. The skin appears flushed and is warm to touch. 4+ reflexes are elicited in the upper and lower extremities. What is the primary mechanism of action of the antitussive responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, autonomic instability, and hyperreflexia. She has been taking fluoxetine and was started on a new antitussive. Together, these findings are concerning for serotonin syndrome. The new medication was most likely dextromethorphan, which works primarily by antagonizing NMDA receptors but also exerts serotonergic effects.     

Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that can be used to relieve cough caused by minor viral upper respiratory tract infections or inhaled irritants. It acts primarily by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors. This medication is a codeine-analog and has mild opioid effects when used in excess. As a result, the medication carries mild abuse potential. Moreover, dextromethorphan can inhibit serotonin reuptake and can precipitate serotonin syndrome, especially when taken in combination with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).    

Side effects, particularly with overdose, include hallucinations, confusion, euphoria, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. In severe cases, patients may experience seizures, coma, and respiratory depression.     

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of muscarinic receptors:
Incorrect: Guaifenesin stimulates muscarinic receptors, which in turn, triggers submucosal glands to produce well-hydrated secretions. Guaifenesin is an expectorant, not an antitussive. Furthermore, guaifenesin would not precipitate serotonin syndrome.  
✅ Blockade of NMDA receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Disruption of disulfide bonds:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that thins mucus by disrupting disulfide bonds. N-acetylcysteine is neither an antitussive nor would it precipitate serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Antagonization of H1 receptors:
Incorrect: Antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine, loratadine, cetirizine) prevent respiratory smooth muscle constriction and mucus production. These medications can be used to treat symptoms of nasal congestion caused by allergies or the common cold. Antihistamines would not trigger serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Inhibition of monoamine oxidase activity:
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. phenelzine, tranylcypromine) are antidepressants that increase serotonin levels and can precipitate serotonin syndrome. However, this patient’s symptoms developed after starting a new antitussive, not a new antidepressant.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after being found down at home with several open pill bottles around him. According to the partner, “He has been so depressed recently, I hope he did not try to hurt himself.” Past medical history includes heart failure, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and major depressive disorder. Home medications include escitalopram, metoprolol, metformin, and digoxin. Temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F), pulse is 32/min, respirations are 7/min, blood pressure is 72/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is obtunded, and the extremities are pale and cool to touch. An electrocardiogram demonstrates sinus bradycardia. Which of the following treatments is the next best step in managing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This critically-ill patient presents following a presumed medication overdose. He has bradycardia and hypotension and appears obtunded on physical examination. Given this clinical picture, the patient most likely overdosed on a β-blocker. The initial step in the management of β-blocker overdose is the administration of intravenous fluids.

Most patients with β-blocker overdose experience bradycardia, hypotension, and unresponsiveness. Treatment follows a step-wise approach that starts with intravenous fluid resuscitation. Next, glucagon, calcium, and atropine should be administered. Glucagon exerts positive inotropic and chronotropic effects independent of the β-adrenergic pathway. Calcium administration helps improve cardiac contractility. Lastly, atropine has antagonist properties at muscarinic receptors, resulting in increased sympathetic tone.

If the interventions mentioned above are unsuccessful, more aggressive treatment options should be considered, including administering high-dose insulin therapy, vasopressors, cardiac pacing, or hemodialysis for select β-blockers. If the patient is in profound cardiogenic shock, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), intravenous fat emulsion therapy, or cardiac assist devices can also be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous crystalloid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous glucagon:
Incorrect: Intravenous glucagon can be administered in the treatment of β-blocker overdose. However, this intervention should be performed only after attempted fluid resuscitation.  
❌ Intravenous lipid emulsion:
Incorrect: Intravenous lipid emulsions can be administered as a treatment for β-blocker overdose. However, this intervention should be attempted only after other adjuncts such as fluid resuscitation and glucagon have been administered.  
❌ Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Incorrect: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a treatment option for patients with β-blocker overdose who are refractory to nearly all other therapies.  
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate can be administered to treat QRS-complex widening in the setting of β-blocker overdose. In contrast, this patient’s electrocardiogram demonstrates only sinus bradycardia but no evidence of QRS-complex widening.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man is currently in the intensive care unit for continued monitoring following admission for septic shock due to pneumonia. The patient has been hospitalized for two weeks and continues to receive intravenous antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedatives/analgesia. The patient is currently intubated and sedated. Temperature is 38 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 101/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99%. During rounds, the patient is noted to have the finding shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is likely responsible for this finding?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This critically ill patient presents with evidence of digital ischemia: a known long-term adverse effect of prolonged use of direct adrenergic agonists (e.g. norepinephrine). Direct adrenergic agonists include a variety of medications including vasopressors, such as epinephrine, norepinephrine, and phenylephrine. Additional agents include isoproterenol, dopamine, albuterol, and dobutamine among many others.  

While each direct adrenergic agent carries specific side effects, some common side effects unique to this class of medications include changes in heart rate (tachycardia or bradycardia), hypertension, palpitations, and anxiety. For example, medications like isoproterenol may result in excess sympathomimetic effects, predominantly arising from the sustained tachycardia. In addition, the medication midodrine may worsen a patient’s baseline hypertension and should be carefully prescribed to this population. In addition, a notable effect of long-term vasopressor use is that of digital ischemia due to prolonged vasoconstriction.    

Option Analysis

✅ Norepinephrine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is a sedative more commonly known to induce hypotension with large doses. Digital ischemia is more commonly associated with prolonged vasopressor usage.   
❌ Fentanyl:
Incorrect: Fentanyl is an opioid-analgesic used for continuous pain relief for ventilated patients. Common complications include constipation and respiratory depression.   
❌ Piperacillin-tazobactam :
Incorrect: Complications associated with piperacillin-tazobactam include hypersensitivity reactions, nephrotoxicity, and hematologic effects (e.g. immune thrombocytopenia).   
❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Complications associated with vancomycin include hypersensitivity reactions (e.g. red man syndrome) and nephrotoxicity. Ototoxicity may also occur but is overall uncommon.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and palpitations for the past hour. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes mellitus type II, and dyslipidemia. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows absent P waves with an irregularly irregular rhythm and nonspecific T wave changes. The patient is given multiple infusions of metoprolol that fail to convert the patient to sinus rhythm. The decision is made to start the patient on intravenous digoxin. The following day, the patient reports multiple episodes of vomiting. He is found to have a heart rate of 40/min with a serum potassium of 5.9 mEq/L and serum digoxin levels of 4.0 ng/mL (normal: 0.8 to 2.0 ng/mL). Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple episodes of vomiting, bradycardia, hyperkalemia, and increased serum digoxin levels after starting intravenous digoxin for atrial fibrillation is most likely having acute digitalis toxicity. The first line of treatment is the administration of digoxin-specific antibody (Fab) fragments.

Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index, and toxicity is common. Renal impairment, electrolyte imbalance, and certain drug interactions further increase the risk of toxicity. Acute toxicity can present with nausea, vomiting, hyperkalemia, and cardiac arrhythmias (sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial tachycardia with AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation). On the contrary, chronic toxicity presents with less profound gastrointestinal symptoms and more significant neurological (e.g., lethargy, fatigue, and confusion) and visual symptoms (e.g., changes in color vision and scotomas).

Treatment of digoxin toxicity depends on the acuity and severity of the symptoms. The patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation should be assessed and stabilized accordingly. Following the acute ingestion of an unknown amount of digoxin, empiric treatment consists of digoxin Fab fragments administration for adults. Fab fragments should be given, especially when the patient presents with hemodynamic instability, hyperkalemia, or end-organ hypoperfusion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer atropine:
Incorrect: Though symptomatic bradycardia or bradyarrhythmia can be treated with atropine if Fab fragments are not immediately available, it would not address the root cause and associated symptoms.  
✅ Administer digoxin-specific antibody (Fab) fragments:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Though hyperkalemia reflects the degree of toxicity and risk of death in patients with acute digoxin intoxication, it does not cause death, and treatment with potassium-lowering agents (e.g., insulin and dextrose, sodium bicarbonate) is not shown to reduce mortality.  
❌ Perform synchronized cardioversion:
Incorrect: Synchronized cardioversion is the appropriate management of unstable supraventricular tachycardia, which presents with regular and narrow QRS complexes with absent P-waves. It has no role in the management of acute digitalis toxicity.  
❌ Administer adenosine:
Incorrect: Adenosine is appropriate initial management of supraventricular tachycardia in a stable patient who presents with tachycardia and narrow QRS complexes without discernible P-waves. It has no role in the management of acute digitalis toxicity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 1-hour history of swelling in her lips and hands. The swelling started after she started taking her morning medications, which were changed at a recent primary care visit. The patient has no fever, pruritus, abdominal pain, or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has no known drug allergies and does not take any supplements. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows swelling of the face and lips leading to difficulty breathing. Stridor is present at rest. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The patient is given epinephrine and emergently intubated. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infiltration of the skin by glycosaminoglycans

questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing angioedema secondary to ingestion of an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (e.g., lisinopril), which is a common medication used for the management of hypertension. It is the most common cause of acquired angioedema.    

Inhibition of ACE results in elevated bradykinin levels due to impaired metabolism.
